required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Measurement of Anterior Chamber Cell Grading Using Ocular Coherence Tomography
clinical_study.official_title: Objective, Prospective Measurement of Anterior Chamber Cell Grading Using Anterior Chamber Ocular Coherence Tomography

lead_sponsor.agency: Rutgers, The State University of New Jersey

clinical_study.source: Rutgers, The State University of New Jersey

brief_summary.textblock: Optical Coherence Tomography (OCT) is routinely used in ophthalmic clinical practice. It uses infrared light to image patient's eyes. Some patients, such as those with an inflammatory disease called uveitis or those who have just undergone cataract surgery, have intraocular inflammation. This intraocular inflammation commonly manifests as cells that can be seen on routine microscopic clinical examination. However, the only currently available method to quantify this intraocular inflammation is by manually counting on the microscopic clinical examination. The investigators plan to use the OCT machine to image patient's eyes. The investigators will then use the images obtained from the OCT to objectively quantify the degree of intraocular inflammation.

primary_outcome.measure: Number of Participants With Identified Inflammatory Cells on OCT Scan
primary_outcome.time_frame: Through study completion, up to 1 year.
primary_outcome.description: This measure pertains to the identification of cells in OCT scan of the participants. The inflammatory cells to be identified refer to white blood cells. The anterior segment OCT scan was used to attempt to identify these cells in the anterior chamber of the eyes of the participants.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in Cell Density Identified by OCT Scans Over Time
secondary_outcome.description: Identification of changes in cell density in OCT scans over time

arm_group.description: Subjects will undergo up to three optical coherence tomography scans.
Control subjects will undergo a brief, non-contact eye exam and then undergo up to three optical coherence tomography scans.

intervention.description: The OCT scan is a brief, non-contact scan of the back of the eye using infrared light. Subjects will see a light and be asked to look forwards while the scan is completed.
This is a brief, non-contact ocular exam.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Age over 18 years old
- Intervention Arm:
- Active anterior chamber inflammation in at least one eye as diagnosed by clinical exam
- One of the following: 1) diagnosis of uveitis OR 2) undergone cataract extraction surgery within the previous 30 days
- Control Arm:
- No active intraocular inflammation based on clinical exam
Exclusion Criteria:
- Corneal opacities in the affected eye
- Anyone judged unable to understand or consent to study participation

link.description: Laser Safety Information. Laser Institute of America 2016.

reference.citation: Kempen JH, Ganesh SK, Sangwan VS, Rathinam SR. Interobserver agreement in grading activity and site of inflammation in eyes of patients with uveitis. Am J Ophthalmol. 2008 Dec;146(6):813-8.e1. doi: 10.1016/j.ajo.2008.06.004. Epub 2008 Aug 8.

Jabs DA, Nussenblatt RB, Rosenbaum JT; Standardization of Uveitis Nomenclature (SUN) Working Group. Standardization of uveitis nomenclature for reporting clinical data. Results of the First International Workshop. Am J Ophthalmol. 2005 Sep;140(3):509-16. Review.
User Manual: SPECTRALIS HRA+OCT. Heidelberg Engineering GmbH;2012.

Agarwal A, Ashokkumar D, Jacob S, Agarwal A, Saravanan Y. High-speed optical coherence tomography for imaging anterior chamber inflammatory reaction in uveitis: clinical correlation and grading. Am J Ophthalmol. 2009 Mar;147(3):413-416.e3. doi: 10.1016/j.ajo.2008.09.024. Epub 2008 Dec 3.
Li Y, Lowder C, Zhang X, Huang D. Anterior chamber cell grading by optical coherence tomography. Invest Ophthalmol Vis Sci. 2013 Jan 9;54(1):258-65. doi: 10.1167/iovs.12-10477.

Igbre AO, Rico MC, Garg SJ. High-speed optical coherence tomography as a reliable adjuvant tool to grade ocular anterior chamber inflammation. Retina. 2014 Mar;34(3):504-8. doi: 10.1097/IAE.0b013e31829f73bd.

Sharma S, Lowder CY, Vasanji A, Baynes K, Kaiser PK, Srivastava SK. Automated Analysis of Anterior Chamber Inflammation by Spectral-Domain Optical Coherence Tomography. Ophthalmology. 2015 Jul;122(7):1464-70. doi: 10.1016/j.ophtha.2015.02.032. Epub 2015 Apr 4.

responsible_party.investigator_affiliation: Rutgers, The State University of New Jersey

provided_document.document_type: Study Protocol and Statistical Analysis Plan

participant_flow.recruitment_details: Ophthalmology clinic, Newark, New Jersey, from 10/26/2016 to 4/1/2018

group.title: Uveitis and Cataract Imaging Group
group.description: Subjects will undergo up to three optical coherence tomography scans. Optical Coherence Tomography (OCT): The OCT scan is a brief, non-contact scan of the back of the eye using infrared light. Subjects will see a light and be asked to look forwards while the scan is completed.

group.title: Control
group.description: Control subjects will undergo a brief, non-contact eye exam and then undergo up to three optical coherence tomography scans. Optical Coherence Tomography (OCT): The OCT scan is a brief, non-contact scan of the back of the eye using infrared light. Subjects will see a light and be asked to look forwards while the scan is completed. Eye Exam: This is a brief, non-contact ocular exam.

baseline.population: 6 subjects with uveitis identified in clinic and enrolled.

certain_agreements.pi_employee: All Principal Investigators ARE employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: There is NOT an agreement between Principal Investigators and the Sponsor (or its agents) that restricts the PI's rights to discuss or publish trial results after the trial is completed.

clinical_results.limitations_and_caveats: Insufficient enrollment and follow up leading to small numbers of subjects analyzed.
